Yes, lack of motivation among individuals is a common concern when it comes to a communist economy. In a communist system, individuals do not receive personal benefits based on their efforts or work, which can lead to a lack of motivation to work hard or innovate. 

Communist economies typically emphasize collective ownership and control of resources. This can mean that individuals may feel a lack of personal stake in the economy, leading to a lack of incentive to work hard or innovate in their respective fields. With no personal profit incentive or the possibility of individual ownership, people may not see the benefit of exerting more effort or taking on more responsibility in their work.

However, proponents of communism argue that the absence of personal gain can lead to the development of a more collaborative and cooperative society, in which people work together for the benefit of all. Proponents of communism also argue that the lack of financial incentives can be compensated by intrinsic motivations like the satisfaction of contributing to society or the pursuit of excellence.

Overall, while critics of communism argue that it can create a lack of motivation among individuals due to the absence of personal gain, proponents argue that there are other motivators beyond personal financial gain that can drive individuals to work hard and innovate.
